div: This tool allows you to have fine grained control over peak parameters by either directly specifying the parameters, or by specifying which parameters should be fit for, and then re-fitting the peak. The Peak Editor also allows you to edit the nuclide associated with this peak, or change the skew or continuum types used for the peak.
To access the Peak Editor dialog, right-click, or on touch devices tap and hold for about a second, within the region of interest (ROI) of an identified peak, and then select "Peak Editor":

If you have multiple peaks next to each other sharing a ROI, the peak nearest where you right-clicked is chosen; while the Peak Editor window is open, you can change the peak it pertains to by using the arrows in the lower left and right portions of the Peak Editor to cycle through the peaks in the ROI.
Check/Uncheck the "Fit" box located to the right of each box you wish to be incorporated in your spectrum.

After changing a parameter value, the change isn't propagated until either the Apply, Accept, or Refit buttons are clicked. Once one of these buttons is clicked the peak rendered on the chart, or values in the Peak Editor table will be updated with the new values.

ul.div: Clicking the Cancel button will revert the peak to the last time you clicked Apply or Refit, or if you haven't clicked Apply or Refit, it will revert the peak back to before you opened the dialog and close the dialog. The application-level undo/redo does not track changes in individual fields, but instead tracks the opening of the dialog, every time the Apply or Refit button is pressed, and when the dialog is accepted or closed.
Closing the dialog via the upper right hand "×" button closes the dialog without applying any changes you may have made since the last time you clicked the apply, or refit buttons.
The Accept button applies any changes you have made, and closes the dialog.

p: These distributions modify only the lower energy tail of the Gaussian peak:

ul.li:
Exp*Gauss: Convolution of Gaussian with left-sided exponential (also known as Exponentially Modified Gaussian or EMG).
Formula: PDF(x) = (1/(2τ)) exp((x-μ)/τ + σ²/(2τ²)) erfc[1/√2 · ((x-μ)/σ + σ/τ)]
Parameters:
• τ (Skew): Exponential decay constant (range: 0.01-15 σ)
See:
Analytical function for fitting peaks in alpha-particle spectra from Si detectors
G. Bortels and P. Collaers (1987)
International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part A. Applied Radiation and Isotopes
Volume 38, Issue 10, 1987, Pages 831-837
https://doi.org/10.1016/0883-2889(87)90180-8

Double Exp*Gauss: Weighted sum of two Exp*Gauss distributions with different decay constants.
Formula: PDF(x) = (1-η)·Exp*Gauss(τ₁) + η·Exp*Gauss(τ₂) where τ₂ = τ₁ + Δτ₂
Parameters:
• τ₁: First exponential decay constant, typically close to σ (range: 0.01-15 σ)
• Δτ₂: Additional decay for second exponential, τ₂ = τ₁ + Δτ₂ (range: 0.0-10 σ)
• η (Weight): Weight of second exponential, where η=0 gives single Exp*Gauss(τ₁) (range: 0.0-1.0)
From Bortels & Collaers 1987 (Eq. 11). Provides additional flexibility for complex tail shapes by combining a short exponential (representing one physical process) with a longer exponential (representing another process).

Gauss+Exp*Gauss: Weighted mixture of Gaussian and Exp*Gauss distributions.
Formula: PDF(x) = (1-R)·Gaussian(x) + R·Exp*Gauss(x)
Parameters:
• R (Mix Ratio): Mixing ratio where R=0 is pure Gaussian, R=1 is pure Exp*Gauss (range: 0.0-1.0)
• τ (Exp*Gauss τ): Exponential decay constant for Exp*Gauss component (range: 0.01-15 σ)
Useful for spectra where the tail is less prominent than pure Exp*Gauss would predict.

GaussExp: An exponential tail stitched to a Gaussian core at a threshold.
Formula: Gaussian for x > μ - α·σ, exponential continuation for x ≤ μ - α·σ
Parameters:
• Skew: Controls both threshold and decay rate (range: 0.01-15)
See:
A simple alternative to the Crystal Ball function
Souvik Das, arXiv:1603.08591
https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.08591

Crystal Ball: A Gaussian core with a power-law low-end tail below a threshold.
Formula: Gaussian for x > μ - α·σ, power-law (x - μ + α·σ)-n for x ≤ μ - α·σ
Parameters:
• α: Threshold in units of σ where tail begins (range: 0.1-10)
• n: Power-law exponent (range: 0.1-50)
See:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_Ball_function

p: These distributions modify both the lower and upper energy tails:

ul.li:
ExpGaussExp: A double-sided version of the GaussExp distribution.
Parameters:
• Lower Skew: Controls left tail threshold and decay (range: 0.01-15)
• Upper Skew: Controls right tail threshold and decay (range: 0.01-15)

Double Sided Crystal Ball: A double-sided version of the Crystal Ball distribution.
Parameters:
• αlow: Lower threshold in units of σ (range: 0.1-10)
• nlow: Lower power-law exponent (range: 0.1-50)
• αhigh: Upper threshold in units of σ (range: 0.1-10)
• nhigh: Upper power-law exponent (range: 0.1-50)

p: These distributions combine multiple profile types for specialized applications:

ul.li:
Voigt+Exp*Gauss: Weighted mixture of Voigt profile and Exp*Gauss distribution.
Formula: PDF(x) = (1-R)·Voigt(x,γ) + R·Exp*Gauss(x,τ)
Parameters:
• γL (Lorentzian γ): Lorentzian HWHM for natural linewidth (range: 0.001-0.5 keV)
• R (Mix Ratio): Mixing ratio where R=0 is pure Voigt, R=1 is pure Exp*Gauss (range: 0.0-1.0)
• τ (Exp*Gauss τ): Exponential decay constant for Exp*Gauss component (range: 0.01-10 σ)
Particularly useful for x-ray peaks where both natural linewidth (Lorentzian) and detector effects (exponential tail) are significant. The Lorentzian component represents the natural x-ray linewidth, while the Exp*Gauss tail accounts for incomplete charge collection.

div: The following are typical reasons to refer to the Peak Editor tool.

ul.li:
Fitting difficult peaks in situations where the default peak fitting algorithm is not satisfactory, or statistics are too low to yield a valid fit.
For instance, you may select for the peak centroid and/or width to not be fit for, and instead supply the value(s) you think are correct, and then refit the peak, thus gaining a more accurate peak area and/or continuum estimate.

Add a label to the peak.
For this label to also show on the chart, select the "Show User Labels" option from the View → Chart Options → Peak Labels menu.

To change the continuum type.
By default peaks are assigned Linear continuums, however changing this may yield better peak fits for regions where the continuum is more complex or a-typical.

Specifying the region of interest (ROI).
By default InterSpec guesses a ROI when fitting peaks, based on the width of the candidate peak (derived from a polynomial smoothing of the second derivative of the data), and a combination of features and statistical of the data - this may not result in the optimum selection of ROI. Specifying the ROI manually and refitting the peak can often times increase the improved estimates of the peak.

Selecting the photopeak of the nuclide responsible for creating this peak.
This dialog allows selecting the gamma-line from a list, rather than typing it in like in other locations.

When refitting a peak, not only is the current peak the Peak Editor is selected for refit, but any peaks that share its ROI are refit as well.
To prevent this, you can either force the current peak to not share a ROI by right-clicking on the peak and selecting the "Own Continuum" option, or you can use the Peak Editor to disable fitting of the various parameters for the other peaks.

Many of the fields do not have error checking beyond verifying a floating point number was entered. For instance you could specify a ROI which does not contain the peak centroid, resulting in the peak not even showing up on the chart.
There can be only one Peak Editor dialog open at a time; trying to open the Peak Editor for a second peak will only change which peak the current dialog corresponds to.

The uncertainties on the parameters initially represent the errors determined from the fitting procedures, however, you should take them with a grain of salt. This is for three reasons:
These values are manually editable, so may not be what the fitting procedure determined
Fixing some parameters may result in much smaller uncertainties being derived for the other parameters, that may in fact be unreasonable.
The uncertainties are estimated from a chi squared, or likelihood, function and it has not been verified that this uncertainty is what is actually seen during use.
